member.name: M:FlatRedBall.AI.Pathfinding.NodeNetwork.GetVisibleNodeRadius(FlatRedBall.Camera,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the radius of the PositionedNode visible representation Polygons.
member.remarks: The size of the PositionedNode visible representation Polygons depends on the camera's Z position - as the Camera moves further away, the Polygons are drawn larger. If the Camera is viewing down the Z axis then changing the Z will not affect the visible size of the PositionedNode visible representation.

member.returns: The radius of the node.

member.summary: Returns the List of PositionedNodes which make the path from the start PositionedNode to the end PositionedNode.
member.remarks: If start and end are the same node then the List returned will contain that node.
member.param: The PositionedNode to begin the path at.
The destination PositionedNode.
member.returns: The list of nodes to travel through to reach the end PositionedNode from the start PositionedNode. The start and end nodes are included in the returned List.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.AI.Pathfinding.NodeNetwork.GetPath(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3@,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3@)
member.summary: Returns the List of PositionedNodes which make the path from the start Vector3 to the end Vector3.
member.remarks: This method finds the closest nodes to each of the arguments, then calls the overload for GetPath which takes PositionedNode arguments.
member.param: The world-coordinate start position.
The world-coordinate end position.
member.returns: The list of nodes to travel through to reach the closest PositionedNode to the endPoint from the closest PositionedNode to the startPoint.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.AI.Pathfinding.NodeNetwork.GetPathOrClosest(FlatRedBall.AI.Pathfinding.PositionedNode,FlatRedBall.AI.Pathfinding.PositionedNode)
member.summary: Returns the List of PositionedNodes which make the path from the start PositionedNode to the end PositionedNode, or the node closest to the end node which is linked through the network to the start PositionedNode.
member.remarks: If start and end are the same node then the List returned will contain that node.
member.param: The PositionedNode to begin the path at.
The optimal destination PositionedNode.
member.returns: The list of nodes to travel through to reach the end PositionedNode, or the node closest to the PositionedNode which is connected to the start PositionedNode, from the start PositionedNode. The start and end nodes are included in the returned List.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.AI.Pathfinding.NodeNetwork.GetPathOrClosest(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3@,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3@)
member.summary: Returns the List of PositionedNodes which make the path from the start Vector3 to the end Vector3, or to the node closest to the end Vector3 available if the end node is not linked in some way to the start node.
member.remarks: This method finds the closest nodes to each of the arguments, then calls the overload for GetPathOrClosest which takes PositionedNode arguments.
member.param: The world-coordinate start position.
The world-coordinate end position.
member.returns: The list of nodes to travel through to reach the closest PositionedNode which is linked to the closest PositionedNode to the startPoint.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.AI.Pathfinding.NodeNetwork.GetCollisionOptimizedPath(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3,FlatRedBall.Math.PositionedObjectList{FlatRedBall.Math.Geometry.Polygon})
member.summary: Returns a List of Vector3s that will be an optimized version of GetPath given the NodeNetwork and a Collision Map to test against.
member.remarks:
This method will get the optimal path between the two vectors using GetPath, and then will optimize it by testing line of sight between the nodes to see if the path can be optimized further (for more optimized pathfinding). When optimizing the path between two nodes, it will check if the midpoint is in line of sight with the startingPosition, and if it is, change the path to the midpoint instead of the current target node. the numberOfOptimizations decides how many times it will take the midpoint and optimize further.
This method assumes that the node network does NOT fall within collidable objects.
member.param: The world-coordinate of the starting position.
The world-coordinate of the destination.
The collision map which will have the obstacles you are trying to path around.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.AI.Pathfinding.NodeNetwork.GetCollisionOptimizedPath(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single,FlatRedBall.Math.PositionedObjectList{FlatRedBall.Math.Geometry.Polygon})
member.summary: Returns a List of Vector3s that will be an optimized version of GetPath given the NodeNetwork and a Collision Map to test against.
member.remarks: This method will get the optimal path between the two vectors using GetPath, and then will optimize it by testing line of sight between the nodes to see if the path can be optimized further (for more optimized pathfinding). When optimizing the path between two nodes, it will check if the midpoint is in line of sight with the startingPosition, and if it is, change the path to the midpoint instead of the current target node. the numberOfOptimizations decides how many times it will take the midpoint and optimize further.
member.param: The world-coordinate of the starting position.
The world-coordinate of the destination.
The number of times the algorithm will take the midpoint between two nodes to test if they are within line of sight of each other (higher means nearer to optimal path).
Usually the object using the path will be larger than 0, use the size of the collision for testing line of sight.
The collision map which will have the obstacles you are trying to path around.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject
member.summary: Represents an object with position, rotation, ability to store instructions, and attachment abilities.
member.remarks:
The PositionedObject is a common object in FlatRedBall. It is the root class for a number of FlatRedBall classes including Sprites, Texts, SpriteFrames, PositionedModels, and all Shapes.
The PositionedObject class is also used as the base class when creating custom Entitiy objects.
PositionedObjects can be automatically managed by being added to the SpriteManager.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Math.IAttachable
member.summary: Interface for an object which can be attached to a parent.
member.remarks: IAttachables do not necessarily have to be positioned objects - they can also be objects which have un-positioned attachments. For example, an event in a scripted sequence might have a parent event which it executes after.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Math.IAttachable.ClearRelationships
member.summary: Clears all attachments to parents and removes all attached Children.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Math.IAttachable.Detach

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Math.IAttachable.ForceUpdateDependencies
member.summary: Forces an update of the instance and calls ForceUpdateDependencies on its parent.
member.remarks: This method will recursively crawl up the Parent property until it reaches the TopParent.

member.remarks: This property provides the two-way relationship between IAttachables and and common FlatRedBall Lists.

member.summary: The list of Instructions that this instance owns. These instructions usually will execute on this instance; however, this is not a requirement.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Position
member.summary: The absolute world position of the instance.
member.remarks: This mirrors the X, Y, and Z properties. This value essentially becomes read-only if this object has a Parent.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativePosition
member.summary: The position of the object relative to its Parent in its Parent's coordinate space.
member.remarks: These values become the dominant controller of absolute Position if this instance has a Parent. These values have no impact if the instance does not have a Parent.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Velocity
member.summary: The absolute world velocity of the instance measured in units per second.
member.remarks: This mirrors the XVelocity, YVelocity, and ZVelocity properties. This value is essentially invalid if this instance has a Parent.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeVelocity
member.summary: The velocity of the object relative to its Parent in its Parent's cooridnate space.
member.remarks: This value modifies the RelativePosition field even if the object does not have a Parent.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Acceleration
member.summary: The absolute world acceleration of the instance measured in units per second per second.
member.remarks:
This mirrors the XAcceleration, YAcceleration, and ZAcceleration properties. This value is essentially invalid if the instance has a Parent; however, it can still build up the Velocity value.
If an object with a parent has a non-zero Acceleration for a significant amount of time, then is detached, the Velocity will likely be non-zero and may be very large causing the object to move rapidly.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.AreSubHierarchiesIdentical(FlatRedBall.PositionedObject,FlatRedBall.PositionedObject)
member.summary: Determines whether the tree structure created by attachments of two PositionedObjects are identical.
member.remarks: This method does not investigate the PositionedObjects any more than looking at their children. It traverses through the trees multiple times, and can be a very slow method if the PositionedObjects have large subtrees. The subtrees are small enough in most cases where there won't be a performance issue.
member.param: The first PositionedObject.
The second PositionedObject.
member.returns: Whether the tree structure created by attachments is the same.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.AttachTo(FlatRedBall.PositionedObject,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Attaches this PositionedObject to the argument newParent.

remarks.para: A useful way to understand the affect of changeRelative is to consider that it is the opposite of whether absolute values change. That is, if the relative values do not change upon attachment, the absolute values will change.

For an example, consider a situation where a child has an absolute x value of 5 and a relative value of 0 and a parent has an absolute x value of 0. If the child is attached to the parent and relative is not changed (relative x remains at 0), then the child's x will be parent.x + child.relX, or 0 + 0 = 0. We see that the relative value didn't change, so the absolute did.

If, on the other hand, the relative was changed, the absolute position would be the same. Since the parent's absolute position was 0 and the absolute position of the child should remain at 5, then the relX value would change to 5 (assuming the parent isn't rotated).

member.param: The PositionedObject to attach to.
Whether relative values should change so that absolute values stay the same.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.ExecuteInstructions(System.Double)

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.ForceUpdateDependencies
member.summary: Forces an update of the PositionedObject's absolute position and rotation values according to its attachment and relative values.
member.remarks:
The absolute positions and rotations of Sprites are updated in the Sprite.UpdateDependencies method which is called in the SpriteManager.UpdateDependencies. The SpriteManager.UpdateDependencies is called once per frame by default in the Sprite's regular activity. This method only needs to be called if changes are made after the UpdateDependencies method has been called for that particular frame or if updated positions are needed immediately after relative values or attachments have been changed.
This method will recur up the hierarchical PositionedObject struture stopping when it hits the top parent.

member.param: The list to fill.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RotationX
member.summary: The x rotation of a PositionedObject
member.remarks:
This rotates the PositionedObject about the X axis. Rotation is represented in radians. Angles will always be greater than or equal to 0 and less than two times PI. Values outside of these bounds will be regulated by the set property.
RotationX can be used to flip an image of a PositionedObject, but a PositionedObject should not be flipped during animation (if it is a Sprite). AnimationFrames can be flipped without setting a Sprite's Rotation values.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RotationY
member.summary: The y rotation of a PositionedObject
member.remarks:
This rotates the PositionedObject about the Y axis. Rotation is represented in radians. Angles will always be greater than or equal to 0 and less than two times PI. Values outside of these bounds will be regulated by the set property.
RotationY can be used to flip an image and set it upside down, but a PositionedObject should not be flipped during animation (if it is a Sprite). AnimationFrames can be flipped without setting a Sprite's Rotation values.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RotationZ
member.summary: The z rotation of a PositionedObject
member.remarks:
This rotates the PositionedObject about the Z axis. Rotation is represented in radians. Angles will always be greater than or equal to 0 and less than two times PI. Values outside of these bounds will be regulated by the set property.
RotationZ can be used to "spin" a PositionedObject, with a positive variable spinning clockwise.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RotationMatrix

member.remarks: The RotationMatrix and RotationX, RotationY, RotationZ reflect eachother. Changing one will change the other.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Drag
member.summary: Linear approximation of drag. This reduces the Velocity of the instance according to its absolute Velocity.
member.remarks:
The following formula is applied to apply Drag:
Velocity -= Velocity * Drag * TimeManager.SecondDifference;

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Camera.SetBordersAtZ(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the visible borders when the camera is looking down the Z axis.
member.remarks: This sets visibility ranges for the camera. That is, if the camera's maximumX is set to 100 at a zToSetAt of 0, the camera will never be able to see the point x = 101, z = 0. The camera imposes these limitations by calculating the actual minimum and maximum values according to the variables passed. Also, the camera keeps track of these visible limits and readjusts the mimimum and maximum values when the camera moves in the z direction. Therefore, it is only necessary to set these values once, and the camera will remeber that these are the visibility borders, regardless of its position. It is important to note that the visiblity borders can be violated if they are too close together - if a camera moves so far back that its viewable area at the set Z is greater than the set minimumX and maximumX range, the camera will show an area outside of this range.
member.param: The minimum x value of the visiblity border.
The minimum y value of the visiblity border.
The maximum x value of the visiblity border.
The maximum y value of the visiblity border.
The z value of the plane to use for the visibility border.

member.summary: Gets and sets the right side of the destination rectangle (where on the window the camera will display). Measured in pixels.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Camera.DestinationRectangle
member.summary: Represents the top left justified area the Camera will draw over.
member.remarks:
This represents the area in pixel coordinates that the camera will display relative to the top left of the owning Control. If the Control is resized, the camera should modify its DestinationRectangle to match the new area.
Multiple cameras with different DestinationRectangles can be used to display split screen or picture-in-picture.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Camera.AspectRatio
member.summary: The width/height of the view of the camera
member.remarks: This determines the ratio of the width to height of the camera. By default, the aspect ratio is 4/3, but this should be changed for widescreen monitors or in situations using multiple cameras. For example, if a game is in split screen with a vertical split, then each camera will show the same height, but half the width. The aspect ratio should be 2/3.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Camera.DrawsCameraLayer
member.summary: Whether the camera draws its layers.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Camera.DrawsWorld
member.summary: Whether the Camera draws world objects (objects not on the Camera's Layer)

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Camera.DrawsShapes
member.summary: Whether the Camera draws shapes

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Camera.FieldOfView
member.summary: The Y field of view of the camera in radians. Field of view represents the Y angle from the bottom of the screen to the top.
member.remarks: This modifies the xEdge and yEdge properties. Default value is (float)Math.PI / 4.0f;

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Camera.Layer
member.summary: A Camera-specific layer. Objects on this layer will not appear in any other cameras.
member.remarks: This instance is automatically created when the Camera is instantiated.

member.summary: Creates a new CameraSave instance using members from the passed Camera argument.
member.param: The Camera to copy properties from.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Content.Scene.CameraSave.SetCamera(FlatRedBall.Camera)
member.summary: Sets the argument Camera's properties to the properties stored in this CameraSave.
member.remarks: Usually "Save" classes include a To[RuntimeType] method. The CameraSave does not follow this pattern because it's most common that a CameraSave is loaded when a Camera is already created by the engine. In this case, it's not very convenient to have to destroy the existing Camera and replace it by a new instance. Instead, the SetCamera method will simply set the properties on an existing Camera
member.param: The Camera to set the properties on.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Animation.AnimationChain.FrameToFrame(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the shortest absolute number of frames between the two argument frame numbers. This method moves forward and backward and considers looping.
member.param: The index of the first frame.
The index of the second frame.
member.returns: The positive or negative number of frames between the two arguments.

member.summary: Sets the frameTime of each AnimationFrame in the AnimationChain to the passed value.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Animation.AnimationChain.TotalLength
member.summary: Returns the sum of the FrameLengths of all contained AnimationFrames.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Animation.AnimationChainList
member.summary: A list of AnimationChains.
member.remarks: This class is often used by IAnimationChainAnimatables to store a list of AnimationChains. Since the AnimationChainList provides a string indexer, it is common to get a reference to an AnimationChain by its name and set it as the IAnimationChainAnimatable's current AnimationChain.

member.summary: Instantiates a new AnimationChainList.

member.summary: Instantiates a new AnimationChainList.
member.param: Sets the initial capacity to reduce memory allocation when subsequently calling Add.

member.summary: Gets and sets whether the AnimationChainList will save the Texture2Ds that its AnimationFrames reference with names relative to the .achx. Otherwise, this property is not used during runtime.

member.summary: Gets or sets the TimeMeasurementUnit. This defaults to TimeMeasurementUnit.Millisecond and should not be changed. It is included for compatability with older versions of FlatRedBall.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Animation.AnimationFrame
member.summary: Stores information about one frame in a texture-flipping animation.
member.remarks: Includes information about which Texture2D to show, whether the Texture2D should be flipped, the length of time to show the Texture2D for, texture coordinates (for sprite sheets), and relative positioning.

member.summary: Empty AnimationFrame.

member.summary: Whether the texture should be flipped horizontally.

member.summary: Whether the texture should be flipped on the vertidally.

member.summary: The bottom coordinate in texture coordinates of the AnimationFrame. Default is 1.

member.summary: The relative X position of the object that is using this AnimationFrame. This is only applied if the IAnimationChainAnimatable's UseAnimationRelativePosition is set to true.

member.summary: The relative Y position of the object that is using this AnimationFrame. This is only applied if the IAnimationChainAnimatable's UseAnimationRelativePosition is set to true.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Layer
member.summary: Layers are objects which can contain other graphical objects for drawing. Layers are used to create specific ordering and can be used to override depth buffer and z-sorted ordering.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Layer.mSprites
member.summary: List of Sprites that belong to this layer. Sprites should be added through SpriteManager.AddToLayer or the AddSprite overloads which include a Layer argument.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Layer.mOverridingFieldOfView
member.summary: Used by the Renderer to override the camera's FieldOfView when drawing the layer. This can be used to give each layer a different field of view.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Layer.Batches
member.summary: The Batches referenced by and drawn on the Layer.
member.remarks:
The Layer stores a regular IDrawableBatch PositionedObjectList internally. Since this internal list is used for drawing the layer the engine sorts it every frame.
For efficiency purposes the internal IDrawableBatch PositionedObjectList cannot be sorted.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Layer.Sprites
member.summary: The Sprites referenced by and drawn on the Layer.
member.remarks:
The Layer stores a regular SpriteList internally. Since this internal list is used for drawing the layer the engine sorts it every frame.
For efficiency purposes the internal SpriteList cannot be sorted.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Layer.Texts
member.summary: The Texts referenced by and drawn on the Layer.
member.remarks:
The Layer stores a regular Text PositionedObjectList internally. Since this internal list is used for drawing the layer the engine sorts it every frame.
For efficiency purposes the internal Text PositionedObjectList cannot be sorted.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Layer.Visible
member.summary: Whether the SpriteLayer is visible.
member.remarks: This does not set the contained Sprite's visible value to false.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Layer.Models
member.summary: The Models referenced by and drawn on the Layer.
member.remarks:
The Layer stores a regular PositionedModel PositionedObjectList internally. Since this internal list is used for drawing the layer the engine sorts it every frame.
For efficiency purposes the internal PositionedModel PositionedObjectList cannot be sorted.

member.returns: The IAttachable with matching name or null if none are found.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Math.AttachableList`1.FindWithNameContaining(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the first IAttachable with a name containing the argument string.
member.remarks: This method returns any IAttachable that has a name that contains the argument. For example, an object with the name "MySprite" would return if the argument was "Sprite".

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Math.AttachableList`1.MakeOneWay
member.summary: Breaks all two-way relationships between this and all contained IAttachables.
member.remarks: This will still contain the same number of IAttachables before and after the call.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Math.AttachableList`1.MakeTwoWay
member.summary: Makes the relationship between all contained IAttachables and this a two way relationship.
member.remarks: If an IAttachable is added (through the Add method), the relationship is already a two-way relationship. IAttachables which already have two-way relationships will not be affected by this call. IAttachables that have been added through the AddOneWay call or added through a call that returns a one-way array will be modified so that they hold a reference to this instance in their ListsBelongingTo field. One-way relationships are often created in FRB methods which return AttachableLists.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Math.PositionedObjectList`1.GetFirstAfterPosition(System.Single,FlatRedBall.Math.Axis,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the first object found after the argument "value" on the argument "axis". Lists must be sorted for this method to work effectively. WARNING: This method uses an inclusive upper bound. Use GetFirstAfter instead which uses an exclusive upper bound.
member.param: The value to search after. For example, this method will return objects with their position values greater than the argument value. In other words, if 0 is passed as the value, then objects with position values greater than (not equal to) will be returned.
The axis representing the value to use (x, y, or z)
The lower (inclusive) bound.
The upper (inclusive) bound. This argument is why GetFirstAfterPosition is obsolete.
member.returns: The index of the first object after the given value.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Math.PositionedObjectList`1.GetFirstAfter(System.Single,FlatRedBall.Math.Axis,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the first object found after the argument "value" on the argument "axis". Lists must be sorted ascending for this method to work effectively.
member.remarks: This method is useful when searching for items in a list after a given value.
member.param: The value to search after. For example, this method will return objects with their position values greater than the argument value. In other words, if 0 is passed as the value, then objects with position values greater than (not equal to) will be returned.
The axis representing the value to use (x, y, or z)
The lower (inclusive) bound.
The upper (exclusive) bound.
member.returns: The index of the first object after the given value.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Content.Model.XLoader.Templates.AnimationOptions
member.summary: This template enables you to set the Direct3D Retained Mode Animation options. The openclosed member can be either 0 for a closed or 1 for an open animation. The positionquality member is used to set the position quality for any position keys specified and can either be 0 for spline positions or 1 for linear positions. By default, an animation is closed.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Content.Model.XLoader.Templates.AnimationOptions.#ctor
member.summary: This template enables you to set the Direct3D Retained Mode Animation options. The openclosed member can be either 0 for a closed or 1 for an open animation. The positionquality member is used to set the position quality for any position keys specified and can either be 0 for spline positions or 1 for linear positions. By default, an animation is closed.

member.summary: An integer value for whether or not the animation using spline or linear positions for interpolation.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Content.Model.XLoader.Templates.AnimationSet
member.summary: An AnimationSet template contains one or more Animation objects and is the equivalent to the Direct3D Retained Mode concept of animation sets. This means each animation within an animation set has the same time at any given point. Increasing the animation set's time will increase the time for all the animations it contains.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Content.Model.XLoader.Templates.MeshNormals
member.summary: This template defines normals for a mesh. The first array of vectors is the normal vectors themselves, and the second array is an array of indexes specifying which normals should be applied to a given face. The value of the nFaceNormals member should be equal to the number of faces in a mesh.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Particle.Emitter
member.summary: An emitter is an invisible object which can create one or more Sprites at a specific rate or on a method call.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Particle.Emitter.mRemovalEvent
member.summary: This is used only in the ParticleEditor.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Particle.Emitter.Emit(FlatRedBall.SpriteList)
member.summary: Emits particles as specified by the Emitter class
member.remarks:
This method initiates one emission of particles. The number of particles emitted depends on the numberPerEmission variable. This method does not consider emission timing, and the time is not recorded for emission timing.
The argument SpriteList stores all Sprites which were emitted during the call. The Sprites are added regularly, rather than in a one way relationship. This enables modification of emitted particles after the method ends. null can be passed as an argument if specific action is not needed for emitted particles. Particles are automatically created through the SpriteManager as Particle Sprites.
member.param: The list of Sprites (which can be null) to add all Sprites created by this call.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Particle.Emitter.SecondsLasting
member.summary: Specifies the number of seconds that particles will remain on the screen and in memory. This is only considered if the RemovalEvent is set to RemovalEventType.TIMED;

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Particle.Emitter.RemovalEventType.None
member.summary: No removal event specified.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Particle.Emitter.RemovalEventType.OutOfScreen
member.summary: Particles will be removed when out of the screen.
member.remarks: This uses the camera's IsSpriteInView method.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Particle.Emitter.RemovalEventType.Alpha0
member.summary: Particles will be removed when Alpha is 0
member.remarks: Setting the Alpha to 0 manually on a particle created by an emitter with this removal event will also remove the Sprite.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Particle.Emitter.RemovalEventType.Timed
member.summary: Particles will be removed after a certain amount of time has passed after emission. This value is set through the SecondsLasting property.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Graphics.Particle.EmitterList
member.summary: List of Emitters provoding shortcut methods for interacting with all contained Emittes.
member.remarks: This is the runtime object created when loading .emix files.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.Window
member.summary: This is the base class for most Gui elements.
member.remarks:
The WindowClass contains common properties, events, and methods used by other Gui elements. Much like most FRB objects, Windows and window sub-classes should be created through the GuiManager.
Windows can be created and drawn two different ways. One is the default Gui. The default is drawn using the guiTex.png graphic. The appearance of the default Gui is similar to a regular Windows Gui. Most default-drawn Gui elements must be added through a Window instance rather than the GuiManager. It is common practice to create a Window through the GuiManager, then to add the children Gui elements through the newly-created Window.
To chnage the appearance of the Gui, most Gui elements can be constructed using SpriteFrames. SpriteFrame-created GuiElements can be created either through the GuiManager or a Window instance.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Window.UpdateDependencies
member.summary: Updates the Window's position according to its Parent's position. Also performs updates on all children.
member.remarks: The GuiManager automatically calls this on all Windows so it's unlikely that this needs to be called outside of the engine. This method does not update the Window's Parents like the UpdateDependencies method does for PositionedObjects because the GuiManager only keeps reference to the top parents of Windows. Therefore, the GuiManager only loops through the top parents and it's their responsibility to update their children's positions.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Window.SetFromWindowSkin(FlatRedBall.Gui.WindowSkin)
member.summary: Sets the SpriteFrame's properties according to the argument WindowSkin.
member.remarks: This allows Window-inheriting UI elements to pass any WindowSkin and control their visibility. For example, a Button may pass a different WindowSkin than a TextBox to this method.
member.param: The WindowSKin to use for setting the SpriteFrame's properties.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Window.Destroy(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Removes self from all Parent Windows, destroys all Children windows, and clears events if keepEvents is false.
member.remarks: This method is called by GuiManager's RemoveWindow method. The GuiManager's RemoveWindow method removes the window from the GuiManager if it is referenced there. This method removes the window from any parents that it belongs to. The two methods together will clear all engine references to the Window.
member.param: Whether to keep all events.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Window.TestCollision(FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor)
member.summary: Calls events for clicking, pushing, dragging, and any other window events.
member.remarks: This method is called either by this instance's parent Window or the GuiManager.
member.param: The Cursor to use for collision.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Window.TestCollisionBase(FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor)
member.summary: Provides acces to base TestCollision functionality for objects which derive from the Window class.
member.remarks:
Sometimes a Window is separated by one or more layers of inheritance from the base Window class. In these cases the Window may want to call the base TestCollision method without going through the immediate class it inherits from.
For example, the Button class inherits from the Window class. The ToggleButtonClass inherits from the Button class. Since the Button class needs to perform different functionality than the Button class when the user interacts with it with the Cursor it needs to be able to "step over" the Button's TestCollision call.
member.param: The Cursor to use for interaction with this element.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver
member.summary: Interface for objects which can receive input from the InputManager.
member.remarks:
This interface should only be used for Gui elements specifically because the GuiManager will change the InputManager.ReceivingInput reference depending on the activity of the cursor and other Gui elements. The InputManager will only keep track of one IInputReceiver at a time, and each IInputReceiver needs to assign itself as the target for input through the static InputManager.ReceivingInput field.
Since this is only used for Gui elements, this interface is rarely used in games.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.OnFocusUpdate
member.summary: Called by the InputManager automatically every frame.
member.remarks: The implementation of this method should raise the FocusUpdate event.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.OnGainFocus
member.summary: Called by the engine automatically when an IInputReceiver gains focus.
member.remarks: The implementation of this method should raise the GainFocus event.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.LoseFocus
member.summary: Called by the engine automatically when an IInputReceiver loses focus.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.ReceiveInput
member.summary: The method called every frame by the InputManager in the Update method if this is the IInputReceiver referenced by the InputManager. This does not have to be called automatically.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.TakingInput
member.summary: A method which determines whether the instance can currently receive focus as an input receiver.
member.returns: Whether the instance is taking input.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.NextInTabSequence
member.summary: The next IInputReceiver in the tab sequence. In other words, if this element is currently receiving input (is the InputManager's ReceivingInput), pressing tab will set the NextInTabSequence to be the InputManager's ReceivingInput.

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.GainFocus
member.summary: Raised when the instance gains input focus (becomes the InputManager's ReceivingInput).

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.FocusUpdate
member.summary: Event raised every frame if there is a non-null InputManager.ReceivingInput. This allows the IInputReceiver to perform custom every-frame logic when it has focus, such as a ListBox listening for the Delete key to delete highlighted elements.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.ListBoxBase.mInsertLocation

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.ListBoxBase.mYPositionPushed
member.summary: When the user pushes the mouse over the list box this value will be set. Then this value can be compared against to see if reordering should occur.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.ListBoxBase.GetItem(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the CollapseItem at index itemNumber traversing from the top of the list down.
member.remarks: This method will skip over items that are children of collapsed items. The list is traversed down ignoring hierarchy, but only counting "visible" items.
member.param: The index to return
member.returns: The item at index itemNumber.

member.summary: Removes the item from the CollapseListBox.
member.remarks: This method removes the item from the CollapseListBox and detaches the item's children and reattaches them to the box. The assumption here is that the item will not be reattached.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.ListBoxBase.NumberOfVisibleElements
member.summary: Returns the number of elements that can be shown in the list box. Increasing the ScaleY or decreasing the DistanceBetweenLines increases this value.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor
member.summary: The cursor is a controllable graphical icon which can interact with FRB elements and stores information about mouse activity.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.sensitivity
member.summary: Controls how sensitive the cursor is to mouse movements.
member.remarks: Default value is 1, so setting the value to 2 will make the mouse twice as sensitive.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.si
member.summary: The Sprite that the cursor uses to draw itself.
member.remarks:
This field can be modified to change how the Sprite is drawn. The following Sprite values modify the cursor:
x - relative to the camera
y - relative to the camera
ScaleX
ScaleY
RotationX
RotationY
RotationZ
texture
fade
visible
Other values will not modify how the Sprite is drawn.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.tipXOffset
member.summary: The x distance from the center of the Cursor which is used as the cursor's tip for selection.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.tipYOffset
member.summary: The y distance from the center of the Cursor which is used as the cursor's tip for selection.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.mWindowSecondaryPushed
member.summary: The window that the cursor was over when the mouse button was pressed.
member.remarks: When the secondary (right) mouse button is pushed down, this value is set - either to null if the mouse is not over any Windows or to the Window that the mouse is over. When the secondary mouse button is released (clicked), this value is set to null. This value is useful for clicking on Windows. Specifically, when the cursor is clicked on a Button, the WindowPushed value is tested to make sure that it is the same as the Window clicked on. This allows for players to push on a Button but move the mouse away and click elsewhere without clicking on the Button originally pushed and without accidentally clicking on other Buttons. This is also used with ToggleButtons to control when they are pressed and unpressed.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.StaticPosition
member.summary: If this value is true, the Cursor will not move in response to the mouse or gamepad.
member.remarks: This value can be set to true if the Cursor should not move in response to input. The staticPosition value is only used by the engine when over the button on an UpDown. When pushing down on an UpDown button, the staticPosition is set to true, and set to false when releasing the mouse button.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.mWindowGrabbed
member.summary: The window that the cursor has grabbed.
member.remarks: When the mouse button is released, the windowGrabbed reference is set to null. If a Window is grabbed, it will move as the mouse moves. This is used commonly for dragging on menu bars and scroll bars. The cursor does not recognize which types of Windows can be dragged, so windows must be grabbed through the Cursor.GrabWindow method. The windowGrabbed's onDrag event is fired every frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.mObjectGrabbed
member.summary: Storage for reference to a grabbed object.
member.remarks: This variable has no internal engine functionality. It merely provies a place to store a reference to a grabbed Object - useful in graphical applications where the Cursor can grab and move objects such as Sprites or Text objects. The ObjectGrabbedRelativeX and ObjectGrabbedRelativeY can also be set to keep the object static after a click rather than "snapping" its center to the Cursor's tip.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ObjectGrabbedRelativeX
member.summary: The relative x position of a grabbed object from the center of the cursor.
member.remarks: This value can be set through the SetObjectRelativePosition. This value used in the GetCursorPositionForSprite method.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ObjectGrabbedRelativeY
member.summary: The relative y position of a grabbed object from the center of the cursor.
member.remarks: This value can be set through the SetObjectRelativePosition. This value used in the GetCursorPositionForSprite method.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.PrimaryPush
member.summary: Determines whether the primary button was pushed this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.PrimaryDown
member.summary: Determines whether the primary button is down this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.PrimaryClick
member.summary: Determines whether the primary button was clicked (released) this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.PrimaryDoubleClick
member.summary: Determines whether the primary button was double clicked this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.SecondaryPush
member.summary: Determines whether the secondary button was pushed this frame.

member.summary: Determines whether the secondary button is down this frame.

member.summary: Determines whether the secondary button was clicked (released) this frame.

member.summary: Determines whether the secondary button was double clicked this frame.

member.summary: Reference to the camera to which the cursor belongs.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.#ctor(FlatRedBall.Camera)
member.summary: Creates a new Cursor
member.remarks: Usually the cursor does not have to be created explicitly. Calling the GuiManager's constructor without a cursor reference (default in the FrbTemplate) creates a cursor automatically. New cursors should only be created if multiple cursors are needed, or if you are inheriting from the Cursor class. Usually multiple cursors are only needed in games with multiple cameras.
member.param: The camera that the cursor will belong to.
Reference to the form that the application is running on.
Reference to the InputManager.
Reference to the SpriteManager

member.summary: Returns the xVelocity of the cursor at a particular Z.
member.remarks: As the cursor can control objects at various Z values, this method returns the X velocity of the cursor at a paritular Z. This method assumes that the Camera is unrotated (looking down the Z axis.
member.param: The z value to measure the velocity at.
member.returns: The X velocity at the particular Z.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ActualYVelocityAt(System.Single)
member.summary: Returns the yVelocity of the cursor at a particular Z.

member.returns: The Y velocity at the particular Z.

The z value to use.

member.remarks: This method assumes that the camera's currentFollowingStyle is Camera.LOOKINGSTYLE.DOWNZ. The x and y arguments will represent the location of the cursor's tip and adds the relative Sprite positions.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.GrabWindow(FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow)
member.summary: Grabs a Window with the Cursor.
member.remarks: The windowGrabbed reference will automatically be set to null when the primary button is released (clicked) by the GuiManager.Control method.
member.param: The Window to grab.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn(FlatRedBall.Sprite)
member.summary: Determines whether the cursor is on a Sprite, but only considers rotation on the z axis (RotationZ).
member.remarks:
This method will not consider whether spriteToTest is rotated on the x or y axes, and assumes that the camera is looking down the Z axis (the Camera is unrotated). Cursor.IsOn3D works properly for any rotation..
This method will not select Sprites which are closer that the camera's nearClipPlane or further than the camera's farClipPlane.
member.param: The Sprite to test if the cursor is over.
member.returns: Whether the cursor is on the Sprite.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn(FlatRedBall.Graphics.Text)
member.summary: Determines whether the cursor is over a textObject.
member.param: The TextObject to test if the cursor is over.
Reference to the TextManager which is used to retrieve dimensions of the Text object.
member.returns: Whether the cursor is on the TextObject.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn(FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow)
member.summary: Returns whether the cursor is over the argument windowToTest.
member.remarks: This method will work accurately for both GuiManager-drawn Windows and SpriteFrame Windows.
member.param: Reference to the window to test.
member.returns: Whether the cursor is over the argument Window.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn``1(``0)
member.summary: Returns whether the cursor is over the argument SpriteFrame.
member.param: Reference to the SpriteFrame to test.
member.returns: Whether the cursor is over the argument SpriteFrame.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn3D(FlatRedBall.Sprite)
member.summary: Determines whether the Cursor is on a Sprite.
member.remarks:
This is the "full featured" version of the IsOn method, considering rotation on all axes for both the spriteToTest and the camera. All lookingStyles are considered and will return accurate results. This method is slower than the IsOn method, and if Sprites are facing the camera under its default orientation, the IsOn method should be used.
This method will not select Sprites if the cursor is over them on a point that is closer that the camera's nearClipPlane or further than the camera's farClipPlane.
member.param: The Sprite to test if the Cursor is over.
member.returns: Whether the Cursor is over the Sprite.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn3D(FlatRedBall.Sprite,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether the Cursor is on a Sprite and stores the intersection point in a Vector3.
member.remarks:
This is the "full featured" version of the IsOn method, considering rotation on all axes for both the spriteToTest and the camera. All lookingStyles are considered and will return accurate results. This method is slower than the IsOn method, and if Sprites are facing the camera under its default orientation, the IsOn method should be used.
This method also modifies a Vector3 which marks the intersection point on the Sprite.
This method will not select Sprites if the cursor is over them on a point that is closer that the camera's nearClipPlane or further than the camera's farClipPlane.
member.param: The Sprite to test if the Cursor is over.
The point where the cursor touches the Sprite.
member.returns: Whether the Cursor is on the Sprite.

member.param: The texture to compare to.
member.returns: Whether the argument is the same as the Cursor's texture.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.XVelocity
member.summary: The change in x since last frame in world units at 100 units away from the camera.
member.remarks: Cursor velocity properties do not counsider bounds; that is, a cursor will still have an xVelocity even if it is pressed against the right side of the screen and being moved to the right.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.YVelocity
member.summary: The change in y since last frame in world units at 100 units away from the camera.
member.remarks: Cursor velocity properties do not counsider bounds; that is, a cursor will still have an xVelocity even if it is pressed against the right side of the screen and being moved to the right.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ZVelocity
member.summary: The movement rate of the controlling input (usually mouse) on the z axis.
member.remarks: Cursor velocity properties do not counsider bounds; that is, a cursor will still have an xVelocity even if it is pressed against the right side of the screen and being moved to the right.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.WindowPushed
member.summary: The window that the cursor was over when the mouse button was pressed.
member.remarks: When the mouse button is pushed down, this value is set - either to null if the mouse is not over any Windows or to the Window that the mouse is over. When the mouse button is released (clicked), this value is set to null. This value is useful for clicking on Windows. Specifically, when the cursor is clicked on a Button, the WindowPushed value is tested to make sure that it is the same as the Window clicked on. This allows for players to push on a Button but move the mouse away and click elsewhere without clicking on the Button originally pushed and without accidentally clicking on other Buttons. This is also used with ToggleButtons to control when they are pressed and unpressed.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ObjectGrabbed
member.summary: Assigns the ObjectGrabbed and calculates the relative position of the grabbed object. After this method is called, UpdateObjectGrabbedPosition can be called every frame to position the grabbed object.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.mDominantWindows
member.summary: A stack of Windows which demand input from the cursor.
member.remarks: When a dominantWindow is valid, the cursor will not be able to interact with other windows. If RemoveInvisibleDominantWindows is set to true (default is true) then the GuiManager will remove any invisible dominant windows from its memory. In other words a DominantWindow can be removed either through the traditional Remove methods or by setting the Window's Visible property to false if RemoveInvisibleDominantWindows is true.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.mToolTipText
member.summary: Sets the tool tip to show
member.remarks: Some UI elements like Buttons automatically show a tool tip. This property can be used to overwrite what is shown, or to show tool tips when the user is over a non-UI element.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.AddDominantWindow(FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow)
member.summary: Adds a window as a Dominant Window. If the window is a regular Window already managed by the GuiManager it will be removed from the regularly-managed windows.
member.param: The window to add to the Dominant Window stack.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.SortZAndLayerBased
member.summary: Sorts all contained IWindows according to their Z values and Layers. This will usually result in clicks being received in the same order that objects are drawn, which is what the user will usually expect

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.AddPerishableWindow(FlatRedBall.Gui.Window)
member.summary: Adds a Window to the GuiManager which will disappear the next time the user clicks.
member.param: The Window to add.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.AddTextureSwitch(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D)
member.summary: Inserts a texture switch in the rendering of the GUI. The argument textureToSwitch will be used to draw just the next quad passed as 6 vertices.
member.remarks:
This method is called from the Draw method of an object that is a Window or inherits from Window. This notifies the GuiManager that the next 6 vertices passed through the GuiManager.verts.Write(v); call will be using a different texture. After those 6 are drawn, the GuiManager continues to draw the rest of the quads using the regular GUI texture.
The important thing to remember is that this method does NOT need to be called in pairs.
member.param: The texture to use for the following quad.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.PropertyGrid.mUndoInstructions
member.summary:
The PropertyGrid can be tied to a list of InstructionLists. These hold the instructions necessary to undo the changes made by the PropertyGrid.
It is common to store a list of lists so that multiple changes can be perfomred during one undo. In other words, if X and Y were changed in one action then the instructions for changing the X and Y back will be in one InstructionList.

member.remarks: For example, if the member is a bool then this method will return a ComboBox. If the member is of a type that does not have a specific UI representation then a button that says "Edit Property" will be returned.
member.param: The name of the member.
member.returns: The UI element that is used to edit this property, or null if the property is not found.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.PropertyGrid`1.ReplaceMemberUIElement(System.String,FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow)
member.summary: Replaces the UI element representing the argument propertyName with the argument newUIElement.
member.remarks: The newUIElement argument should not already be added to the GuiManager or to the PropertyGrid. This method should be called BEFORE any UI events are added to the newUIElement argument. This guarantees that the PropertyGrid events are fired first, then the custom events can be used to modify the object shown by the PropertyGrid.
member.param: The name of the property to replace the UI element for.
The new UI element for the property. This should be created with a new call, not added to this instance or the GuiManager.

member.summary: Object which holds a list of strings that can be used to tell the PropertyGrid which members to exclude when creating a new PropertyGrid of a specific type.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.PropertyGrids.BoolPropertyGrid
member.summary: A StructReferencePropertyGrid used by the FlatRedBall Engine when editing bools in a ListDisplayWindow.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.StructReferencePropertyGrid`1
member.summary: A class that can be used to apply changes to fields and properties of an object.
member.remarks:
If an object has a Vector3 field, creating a regular PropertyGrid for that Vector3 and changing that Vector3 will not actually change the field's value. Since C# doesn't have pointers, then the only way to change the source's field is to keep a reference to the object that has the field, then push changes through that instance.
The StructReferencePropertyGrid simulates a pointer by storing reference to the object that contains the field.
member.typeparam: The type of object that the PropertyGrid stores.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.PropertyGrids.DoublePropertyGrid
member.summary: A StructReferencePropertyGrid used by the FlatRedBall Engine when editing doubles in a ListDisplayWindow.

member.summary: A StructReferencePropertyGrid used by the FlatRedBall Engine when editing enums in a ListDisplayWindow.

member.summary: Settings which can be used to set the visibility of member elements depending on the value of another member.
member.remarks: This enum is used by MemberVisibleCondition which is used in the PropertyGrid's SetConditionalMemberVisibility method to set how the state of one property can impact the visibility of another property.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.PropertyWindowAssociation
member.summary: Base non-generic class for the generic PropertyWindowAssociation class.
member.remarks: Contains information about an element in the PropertyGrid. Information includes the UI element displaying the property, its associated Label, the member name, read/write permissions, and category.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.PropertyWindowAssociation.Window
member.summary: The window that allows for editing of the property.
member.remarks: Fore example, a bool property would have a ComboBox.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.PropertyWindowAssociation.IsViewable
member.summary: When a property is not a base type understood by the PropertyGrid it is represented by a button. These properties can then be viewed in their own PropertyGrid. Even if CanWrite is false on these properties the user should still be able to view them. If CanWrite is false but this is true then the UI (button) representing this property will be enabled.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.PropertyWindowAssociation.ChildFloatingWindow
member.summary: The window that allows for more detailed editing of an object. This window will appear if the user clicks on an "Edit Property" button.
member.remarks:
Some types like ints and floats have natural representations, but other custom types do not. Therefore if a member that the PropertyGrid does not how to display is included, then the PropertyGrid will show a button that says "Edit Property". Pressing this button will bring up a new window which will show the details of an object in a new PropertyGrid or ListBox. This will hold the reference to the window.
Holding the reference not only eliminates some garbage collection and memory allocation, but it also allows the user to get a reference to it to add events for custom behavior.

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.PropertyWindowAssociation.ChangeEvent
member.summary: Raised whenever a property is changed through the PropertyGrid.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.PropertyWindowAssociation`1
member.summary: Generic class storing associations between UI elements and settings for the member in the PropertyGrid.
member.typeparam: The type of the member being shown.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.mDPadOnValue
member.summary: The mDPadOnValue and mDPadOffValue values are used to simulate D-Pad control with the analog stick. When the user is above the absolute value of the mDPadOnValue then it is as if the DPad is held down. To release the DPad the value must come under the off value. If there was only one value then the user could hold the stick near the threshold and get rapid on/off values due to the inaccuracy of the analog stick.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.Angle
member.summary: Returns the angle of the analog stick. 0 is to the right, Pi/2 is up, Pi is to the left, and 3*Pi/2 is down.

member.summary: Gets the distance from the center position of the analog stick.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.Position
member.summary: The position of the analog stick. The range for each component is -1 to 1.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Instructions.InstructionManager.Instructions
member.summary: Holds instructions which will be executed by the InstructionManager in its Update method (called automatically by FlatRedBallServices).
member.remarks: Instructions for managed PositionedObjects like Sprites and Text objects should be added to the object's internal InstructionList. This prevents instructions from referencing removed objects and helps with debugging. This list should only be used on un-managed objects or for instructions which do not associate with a particular object.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Instructions.InstructionSet
member.summary: Represents a set of KeyframeLists which can be applied to objects or used to perform scripted events.
member.remarks:
When used to perform scripted events, InstructionSets can be compared to texture animation. There are many levels of Lists in an InstructionSet. The following comparison to AnimationChainLists provides some clarity to the layers:
InstructionSet (List of KeyframeLists) : AnimationChainList (List of AnimationChains)
KeyframeList (List of Keyframes - aka InstructionLists) : AnimationChain (List of AnimationFrames)
InstructionList (Applied to an object to change any properties) : AnimationFrame (Applied to an object to change its appearance);

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.IO.FileManager.GetAllFilesInDirectory(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns a List containing all files which match the fileType argument which are in the directory argument or a subfolder. This recurs, returning all files.
member.param: String representing the directory to search. If an empty string is passed, the method will search starting in the directory holding the .exe.

The file type to search for specified as an extension. The extension can either have a period or not. That is ".jpg" and "jpg" are both valid fileType arguments. An empty or null value for this parameter will return all files regardless of file type.
member.returns: A list containing all of the files found which match the fileType.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.IO.FileManager.GetAllFilesInDirectory(System.String,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a List containing all files which match the fileType argument which are within the depthToSearch folder range relative to the directory argument.
member.param: String representing the directory to search. If an empty string is passed, the method will search starting in the directory holding the .exe.

The file type to search for specified as an extension. The extension can either have a period or not. That is ".jpg" and "jpg" are both valid fileType arguments. An empty or null value for this parameter will return all files regardless of file type.
The depth to search through. If the depthToSearch is 0, only the argument directory will be searched.
member.returns: A list containing all of the files found which match the fileType.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.IO.FileManager.IsGraphicFile(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether a particular file is a graphical file that can be loaded by the FRB Engine.
member.remarks: This method does conducts the simple test of looking at the extension of the filename. If the extension inaccurately represents the actual format of the file, the method may also inaccurately report whether the file is graphical.
member.param: The file name to test.
member.returns: Whether the file is a graphic file.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Checksums.Adler32
member.summary:
Computes Adler32 checksum for a stream of data. An Adler32 checksum is not as reliable as a CRC32 checksum, but a lot faster to compute.
The specification for Adler32 may be found in RFC 1950. ZLIB Compressed Data Format Specification version 3.3)
From that document:
"ADLER32 (Adler-32 checksum) This contains a checksum value of the uncompressed data (excluding any dictionary data) computed according to Adler-32 algorithm. This algorithm is a 32-bit extension and improvement of the Fletcher algorithm, used in the ITU-T X.224 / ISO 8073 standard.
Adler-32 is composed of two sums accumulated per byte: s1 is the sum of all bytes, s2 is the sum of all s1 values. Both sums are done modulo 65521. s1 is initialized to 1, s2 to zero. The Adler-32 checksum is stored as s2*65536 + s1 in most- significant-byte first (network) order."
"8.2. The Adler-32 algorithm
The Adler-32 algorithm is much faster than the CRC32 algorithm yet still provides an extremely low probability of undetected errors.
The modulo on unsigned long accumulators can be delayed for 5552 bytes, so the modulo operation time is negligible. If the bytes are a, b, c, the second sum is 3a + 2b + c + 3, and so is position and order sensitive, unlike the first sum, which is just a checksum. That 65521 is prime is important to avoid a possible large class of two-byte errors that leave the check unchanged. (The Fletcher checksum uses 255, which is not prime and which also makes the Fletcher check insensitive to single byte changes 0 - 255.)
The sum s1 is initialized to 1 instead of zero to make the length of the sequence part of s2, so that the length does not have to be checked separately. (Any sequence of zeroes has a Fletcher checksum of zero.)"

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Checksums.IChecksum
member.summary: Interface to compute a data checksum used by checked input/output streams. A data checksum can be updated by one byte or with a byte array. After each update the value of the current checksum can be returned by calling getValue. The complete checksum object can also be reset so it can be used again with new data.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater
member.summary:
This is the Deflater class. The deflater class compresses input with the deflate algorithm described in RFC 1951. It has several compression levels and three different strategies described below.
This class is not thread safe. This is inherent in the API, due to the split of deflate and setInput.
author of the original java version : Jochen Hoenicke

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.BEST_COMPRESSION
member.summary: The best and slowest compression level. This tries to find very long and distant string repetitions.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.BEST_SPEED
member.summary: The worst but fastest compression level.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.DEFAULT_COMPRESSION
member.summary: The default compression level.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.NO_COMPRESSION
member.summary: This level won't compress at all but output uncompressed blocks.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.DEFLATED
member.summary: The compression method. This is the only method supported so far. There is no need to use this constant at all.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new deflater with default compression level.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new deflater with given compression level.
member.param: the compression level, a value between NO_COMPRESSION and BEST_COMPRESSION, or DEFAULT_COMPRESSION.
member.exception: if lvl is out of range.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new deflater with given compression level.
member.param: the compression level, a value between NO_COMPRESSION and BEST_COMPRESSION.
true, if we should suppress the Zlib/RFC1950 header at the beginning and the adler checksum at the end of the output. This is useful for the GZIP/PKZIP formats.
member.exception: if lvl is out of range.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Reset
member.summary: Resets the deflater. The deflater acts afterwards as if it was just created with the same compression level and strategy as it had before.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Flush
member.summary: Flushes the current input block. Further calls to deflate() will produce enough output to inflate everything in the current input block. This is not part of Sun's JDK so I have made it package private. It is used by DeflaterOutputStream to implement flush().

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Finish
member.summary: Finishes the deflater with the current input block. It is an error to give more input after this method was called. This method must be called to force all bytes to be flushed.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetInput(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Sets the data which should be compressed next. This should be only called when needsInput indicates that more input is needed. If you call setInput when needsInput() returns false, the previous input that is still pending will be thrown away. The given byte array should not be changed, before needsInput() returns true again. This call is equivalent to setInput(input, 0, input.length).
member.param: the buffer containing the input data.
member.exception: if the buffer was finished() or ended().

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetInput(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the data which should be compressed next. This should be only called when needsInput indicates that more input is needed. The given byte array should not be changed, before needsInput() returns true again.
member.param: the buffer containing the input data.
the start of the data.
the number of data bytes of input.
member.exception: if the buffer was Finish()ed or if previous input is still pending.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetLevel(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the compression level. There is no guarantee of the exact position of the change, but if you call this when needsInput is true the change of compression level will occur somewhere near before the end of the so far given input.
member.param: the new compression level.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.GetLevel
member.summary: Get current compression level
member.returns: Returns the current compression level

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetStrategy(ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.DeflateStrategy)
member.summary: Sets the compression strategy. Strategy is one of DEFAULT_STRATEGY, HUFFMAN_ONLY and FILTERED. For the exact position where the strategy is changed, the same as for SetLevel() applies.
member.param: The new compression strategy.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Deflate(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Deflates the current input block with to the given array.
member.param: The buffer where compressed data is stored
member.returns: The number of compressed bytes added to the output, or 0 if either IsNeedingInput() or IsFinished returns true or length is zero.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Deflate(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Deflates the current input block to the given array.
member.param: Buffer to store the compressed data.
Offset into the output array.
The maximum number of bytes that may be stored.
member.returns: The number of compressed bytes added to the output, or 0 if either needsInput() or finished() returns true or length is zero.
member.exception: If offset or length don't match the array length.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetDictionary(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Sets the dictionary which should be used in the deflate process. This call is equivalent to setDictionary(dict, 0, dict.Length).
member.param: the dictionary.
member.exception: if SetInput () or Deflate () were already called or another dictionary was already set.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetDictionary(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the dictionary which should be used in the deflate process. The dictionary is a byte array containing strings that are likely to occur in the data which should be compressed. The dictionary is not stored in the compressed output, only a checksum. To decompress the output you need to supply the same dictionary again.
member.param: The dictionary data
The index where dictionary information commences.
The number of bytes in the dictionary.
member.exception: If SetInput () or Deflate() were already called or another dictionary was already set.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.DeflaterEngine.prev
member.summary: prev[index & WMASK] points to the previous index that has the same hash code as the string starting at index. This way entries with the same hash code are in a linked list. Note that the array should really be unsigned short, so you need to and the values with 0xffff.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Inflater
member.summary:
Inflater is used to decompress data that has been compressed according to the "deflate" standard described in rfc1951.
By default Zlib (rfc1950) headers and footers are expected in the input. You can use constructor public Inflater(bool noHeader) passing true if there is no Zlib header information
The usage is as following. First you have to set some input with SetInput(), then Inflate() it. If inflate doesn't inflate any bytes there may be three reasons:
IsNeedingInput() returns true because the input buffer is empty. You have to provide more input with SetInput(). NOTE: IsNeedingInput() also returns true when, the stream is finished.
IsNeedingDictionary() returns true, you have to provide a preset dictionary with SetDictionary().
IsFinished returns true, the inflater has finished.
Once the first output byte is produced, a dictionary will not be needed at a later stage.
author of the original java version : John Leuner, Jochen Hoenicke

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.InflaterInputStream
member.summary:
This filter stream is used to decompress data compressed using the "deflate" format. The "deflate" format is described in RFC 1951.
This stream may form the basis for other decompression filters, such as the GZipInputStream.
Author of the original java version : John Leuner.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator
member.summary:
This class allows us to retrieve a specified number of bits from the input buffer, as well as copy big byte blocks.
It uses an int buffer to store up to 31 bits for direct manipulation. This guarantees that we can get at least 16 bits, but we only need at most 15, so this is all safe.
There are some optimizations in this class, for example, you must never peek more than 8 bits more than needed, and you must first peek bits before you may drop them. This is not a general purpose class but optimized for the behaviour of the Inflater.
authors of the original java version : John Leuner, Jochen Hoenicke

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a default StreamManipulator with all buffers empty

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.PeekBits(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the next sequence of bits but don't increase input pointer. bitCount must be less or equal 16 and if this call succeeds, you must drop at least n - 8 bits in the next call.
member.param: The number of bits to peek.
member.returns: the value of the bits, or -1 if not enough bits available. */

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.DropBits(System.Int32)
member.summary: Drops the next n bits from the input. You should have called PeekBits with a bigger or equal n before, to make sure that enough bits are in the bit buffer.
member.param: The number of bits to drop.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.GetBits(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the next n bits and increases input pointer. This is equivalent to followed by , except for correct error handling.
member.param: The number of bits to retrieve.
member.returns: the value of the bits, or -1 if not enough bits available.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.SkipToByteBoundary
member.summary: Skips to the next byte boundary.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.CopyBytes(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies bytes from input buffer to output buffer starting at output[offset]. You have to make sure, that the buffer is byte aligned. If not enough bytes are available, copies fewer bytes.
member.param: The buffer to copy bytes to.
The offset in the buffer at which copying starts
The length to copy, 0 is allowed.
member.returns: The number of bytes copied, 0 if no bytes were available.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.Reset
member.summary: Resets state and empties internal buffers

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.ManagedSpriteGroups.SpriteFrame.UpdateInternalSpriteNames
member.summary: Sets the contained DynamicSpriteFrame to help identify SpriteFrame membership and side.
member.remarks:
If the SpriteFrame's name is "spriteFrame1", each side will have its name be the SpriteFrame's name with a suffix indicating the side that the Sprite represents. That is, the center Sprite would be named "spriteFrame1_center", the top would be "spriteFrame1_top", and so on.
This method can be used in debugging to help identify whether DynamicSprites belong to a SpriteFrame, and if so, which side they represent. Otherwise, this method has no engine functionality.
